newsitem.title: MEXICO: Volcanic ash could help Mexican coffee crops.
newsitem.headline: Volcanic ash could help Mexican coffee crops.

text.p: A sprinkle of volcanic ash over key Mexican coffee growing regions could be a boon to crops, growers say.
Small amounts of ash landed in coffee-rich Puebla and Veracruz states when rumbling Popocatepetl volcano erupted with its greatest force in 70 years on July 1, leaving farmers clamoring for more.
"It would be fabulous it we got ash here because it carries many nutrients and minerals and we spend a lot on fertilizer," Veracruz coffee farmer Porfirio Hernandez Canales told Reuters.
Coffee growers said volcanic ash has fortified Nicaraguan and Colombian coffee producing regions, enriching the soil with vital nutrients.
Veracruz and Puebla are Mexico's second and third largest coffee producers, respectively. The states are about 95 to 125 miles (150 to 200 km) east of the volcano.
"The dominant winds come from the Gulf of Mexico, in the opposite direction from the volcano. It is impossible for there to be damage here because it is so far," Hernandez said.
Coffee producers cast doubt on volcanic ash hurting the harvest, joking it may just toast coffee beans on the trees.
It would need an unusual wind formation and a full-scale eruption to seriously threaten the nation's coffee crops, they said.

"The worst-case scenario would be if the volcano really started to spew ash and the winds blew it into the coffee regions. It would have to fall extra thick to harm the trees," Weather Services Corp's Mike Palmerino said.
A thick blanket of ash in the plants' growing stage could cut back on photosynthesis, and keep the beans from growing properly, he added.
But barring those unusual circumstances, Palmerino said a volcano blast would have "essentially no effect on the coffee growing regions."
